Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Verification of Coherent Perfect Rotation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to conduct a rigorous "proof of principle" experimental test of coherent perfect rotation (CPR), which is a first example of a hermitian (thus reversible), multiport, 100% quantum efficient optical mode conversion process. Hermitian "coherent perfect" processes are a generalization of the antilaser (coherent perfect absorption, or CPA that combines wave interference with a (sufficiently large) time reversal symmetry breaking transport process. The PIs have shown theoretically that CPR can optimize the optical efficiency and contrast in many optical devices including cavity-based laser frequency locks, opto-magnetic sensors, and optical modulators.
Intellectual Merit:
The theory of CPR is relatively complete, simple and subtle. As a general result of linear optics, CPR provides useful insights into optimizing optical systems with components as ubiquitous and prosaic as beam splitters and cavities. This understanding of fundamental symmetry (time-odd optical elements) combined with coherence may be used to improve select non-linear optical processes as well. Verification of CPR will be a first step in the extension and diffusion of this methodology for improving optical design and devices.
Broader Impacts:
Because this research illuminates the use of fundamental symmetries and coherence in optimizing quantum efficiency, experimentally verifying the method is of value for a broad array of optical devices and protocols, and may ultimately inform commercial optical design.
Testing CPR will involve mentoring a postdoc and undergraduate physics and engineering students, through their inclusion in the Photonic, Electronic, and Optical Materials (POEM) research group at YSU.
Their participation will include extensive, novel laboratory work, co-authorship of scientific publications (for some of the students it will be their first peer-reviewed scientific publication) and presentation of research findings at national meetings. The PIs have a proven record of successful and effective post-doc mentoring.
The PIs have long-standing commitments to science education in northeast Ohio through YAPA (a teacher outreach program active since the 1970's, initiated during the PSSC era) and the Ohio Section of the American Physical Society (OSAPS) and the regional American Association of Physics Teachers (AAPT). The PIs will use activity generated by this research support in outreach by promoting public interest in science and exciting younger students about the innovative careers opportunities in technical fields (primarily Physics and Electrical Engineering).

POR.DRECONTENT: The EAGER: Verification of Coherent Perfect Rotation, (Federal Award ID: 1360725) grant supported the first ever test of a new method for improving the optical efficiency of a a large class of devices that non-destructively process light.  What's more, the method is simple enough to be applicable to many different wave-based phenomena and technologies. Light has a few basic attributes.  Everyone knows already about intensity and color, but light also has phase and polarization.  "Phase" is basically timing differences between two or more waves. Sound is also a wave somewhat like light, and manipulating the intensity, pitch and phase of reproduced sound is how those noise-cancelling headphones work. You may also recall learning that there are transverse and longitudinal waves, and that these names indicate what direction stuff that makes up the wave is shaking. In light the electric and magnetic fields are shaking, and they point and evolve transverse to the motion of the wave (unlike sound waves which are longitudinal). Of course, since the path of the light is along one direction, the other two directions indicate the possible polarization of the wave. As light  goes through a glass-like material, the plane of the polarization of the light can change in predictable and technologically useful ways.  But light is often reflected somewhat at the air-glass interfaces, leading to often substantial (10%-level) inefficiencies, inefficient in that not all the light goes through the material and has its polarization rotated. We proposed that it is possible to combine (from both sides) light on a glass polarization rotator, adjusting the color, intensities and phase, in such a way as to make the rotation potentially 100% efficient. In this process there is effectively no reflection, and all the light that emerges is forced to go through the glass (and have its polarization rotated). One last thing that turns out to be key; theory indicated that this was only possible if the glass was immersed in a magnetic field, for example, directed along the light path, using a process called Faraday Rotation, after Michael Faraday who first observed this effect and correctly understood it (before James Clerk Maxwell's theory unifying light and electricity) as revealing the intrinsic electromagnetic nature of light.  To take these ideas beyond theory and to test them experimentally we needed help, mostly in the form of a postdoctoral research associate skilled in optics and some equipment and some stipend support for our undergraduate physics students who participated in this experiment primarily during the summers of 2014 and 2015.  The postdoctoral research associate funded by this grant, Dr. Chuanhong Zhou, was essential to the substantial setup, testing, and experimental data collection that was necessary to test this theory, and he also trained many students and with us wrote papers (2 already appeared in high impact peer-reviewed physics journals, one additional currently under review) and grants (one with the NSF, not funded,  and some smaller grants) during his year in our research group at YSU. The basic Coherent Perfect Rotation (CPR) experiments were concluded in the later part of 2014 and first part of 2015, and in the remaining months of 2015 a paper was prepared and submitted for publication. The upshot of this work is that we were able to show experimentally that our setup, at particular colors and phases, had reduced the unprocessed part of the light to fractions of a percent. This latest paper on the experimental verification of the theory is currently under review at Physical Review Letters, a high impact peer-reviewed physics journal.
